text: Number 631, Alvin R. Campbell et al., Petitioner, versus United States.
The Interview Report, yes, Your Honor.
That's what we call it, was it in --
When Campbell was here, we called it the Interview Report.
It's the one that's in the footnote?
Yes, it was -- it was footnoted in the official opinion.
-- are you talking about that report which we said out verbatim in the footnote in Campbell?
You don't get to this question Mr. Louison, if in fact Judge Wyzanski was right that the Interview Report was producible either as a statement under (e) (1) or (e) (2), do you?
Except in one instance Mr. Justice Brennan where it was stated in the Campbell case.

No, I mean, do we get to the question of the destruction and consequences of the destruction of the FBI agent's original notes if in fact Judge Wyzanski was right but you were entitled to the Interview Report as a statement under (e) (1) or (e) (2)?

Only reading from the Campbell case, Your Honor and the opinion says, “Does -- even if the Interview Report itself were producible, a situation might have arisen calling for decision whether subsection (d) of the statute required the striking of the testimony of the witness.”
Well, I -- are you then suggesting that even though you are entitled to the report and not having had it therefore that there must be a new trial?
That this -- has -- now to be decided also whether Staula is not to testify because the agent's original notes were destroyed?
Well, now Judge Wyzanski didn't quite make that finding, did he?
I was just wondering, Mr. Louison, we do have findings, six of them. Judge Wyzanski based on all of the evidence of the merits.
Apparently, the Court of Appeals seems to think it might, but is there a question here in how far even the Court of Appeals or indeed we may go back to those findings?
I would say so, Your Honor.
Should not go behind the (Voice Overlap) --
That neither the Court of Appeals should nor should we?
I would say that that is correct, Your Honor.
Well, if that's so, then it doesn't really help to go back into the testimony, does it?
That is -- well, except as you pointed out that finding number three on page 131 of the record.
That's a -- after -- I take it in the sense, these are findings of what we come to call historical facts, what happened in exactly the way it was done?
In the taking of the Interview Report?
Now if they're supported by evidence, should we go behind it?
Well, how much of the proceedings before Judge McCarthy are now relevant to any question we have here?

The Court of -- I would say, Your Honor, strictly academically, probably none, but except that the Court of Appeals in its conclusion when it said the decision of the District Court is affirmed and the convictions will stand, we're affirming the decision of Judge McCarthy and his entry of the judgments of conviction, and the sentences that went with it.
That's the fact that on the question whether -- on the questions --
-- you have brought here namely whether -- this indeed was a statement producible under (e) (1) or (e) (2), and secondly, the consequences of the destruction of the original notes.
I would say no, Your Honor, not as you've stated it, certainly not?
I take it as I have stated it.
I'm trying to find out what --
Although the Court of Appeals apparently seemed to have sent this back to Judge Wyzanski almost just as a master to make these findings --
-- submit a master's report or something like that.
I'm glad you used that phrase, Your Honor, because I think they treated it as an equity appeal.
I'm having -- but we have to go through all these in every Jencks case.
Well, if I may go to the word copy, Your Honors, it's very obvious that the original notes have been destroyed.
You don't think that it was used in the sense of counterpart.
You don't think that in the opinion copy was used in the sense of counterpart?
You have not stated that anything was reduced to writing, Your Honor.
Apparently, it is not producible Your Honor.
But depends on who the witness is, doesn't it?
Well of course -- yes, under the -- yes, of course, if that were the -- if the witness were the agent that is so because I think that was ruled in the Clancy case.
Well, that was clearly within it.
If the agent is the witness we're talking about --
-- and then his statement is verbatim.
And it's not a matter of being producible to me.
I think it would be more on [Inaudible] --
I really can't differentiate Your Honor.
Well, of course we don't know how much time of that 30 minutes was used by the agent himself.
I don't interpret it along the lines you're asking at all respectfully Your Honor.

Mr. Chief Justice, Your Honors, I respectfully submit that the finding of the Court and the record in support of the FBI Interview Report that as in the record and was previously set out in your former Campbell opinion that that is producible.
Yes, but Mr. O'Donnell, I thought --
Yes I am Your Honor but I --
But I thought he introduced jottings.
Well, then why blame the Government?
I certainly wouldn't but I just drew that analogy, may it please, Mr. Justice Brennan, on the proposition that the record doesn't bear out these key phrases and abbreviations.
I would say, may it please, Mr. Justice Goldberg that is producible under both sections.

And for a legal definition of what a statement is in the trial of a case, I would say that is substantially verbatim, the agent treats with 500 words, Mr. Staula's approach to the bank, his observations outside the bank before he entered, his observations upon entering the teller's window, he walked up to what he heard, what he saw.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

But Mr. Solicitor General, I don't -- if what you're going to end up with is that there's something relevant in what happened before Judge McCarthy that the issues now before us, the decision, I must confess I had considerable trouble because the Court of Appeals said that Judge McCarthy had a committed view and sent the matter back to Judge Wyzanski and I must say I read that as meaning in effect that they wipe the slate clean and had Judge Wyzanksi do it.
I submit -- I submit not Your Honor, if you look at the Court of Appeals --
Well, if that's so, if that's so then there's going to be a question here whether it was compliance with our mandate.
Well, I'd say there was no -- on the Court of Appeals' own analysis of what happened before Judge McCarthy, Judge McCarthy didn't do the job that we sent the case back to have it done.
The Court felt that he had properly done all but one part of it.
Well, if it did then I must say I have still greater trouble.
And it sent it back because the matter of adopted or approved had not been properly resolved before Judge McCarthy.
Oh, instead he had a committed view if that doesn't --
Yes, but the -- it's beyond that point that we're different.
Now what authority did it have to make the finding?
It found that the record was -- the records were all there.
I think -- what if we already -- that it have under our mandate to make findings independently.
-- to the District Court for (Voice Overlap) --
I take it if the record would permit only one finding that that would be entirely a problem.
It wasn't really made by him either, was it?
The written statement was not made by him.

The written statement was not made by the witness and it was not adopted or approved by him. Indeed, the fact is, of course, it was made at least six hours and perhaps seven or eight hours after the agent had last seen the witness, so it couldn't have been adopted.
Well, that -- if it is a copy of the notes.
No, I must disagree with Your Honor on the statement.

Having the notes in front of him, he may gave what he called a narrative account of what the witness had said and he gave an illustration that I will develop after the luncheon recess, Mr. Chief Justice which -- in order to illustrate what he did, that Judge Wyzanski and I think it was very useful, asked him -- what I'll show you -- show me what you did and take your Interview Report as a basis and he did it.
Mr. Chief Justice, may I please the Court.
Well, I think one -- I'll address myself with that right now.
Well, I felt very sure it is, Justice Brennan.
Well, I thought it sent it back to Judge Wyzanski to see whether the notes had been read back and approved.
[Inaudible] was that all that was involve in (e) (1)?
But that wouldn't make the Interview Report producible under (e) (1) unless there was testimony showing that the Interview Report was truly a copy of the notes.

Well, we also -- yes, of course, we also have a finding back on page 131 where he says, Toomey did not purport to read the jottings on the pad, just the order they appeared with the scrupulous care that one stenographer would read back to another.
[Inaudible] as to what happened before Judge McCarthy on that [Inaudible].
This issue was sent back to Judge Wyzanski, yes.
No, no, no that was not.
But he did get to that issue.
He did get to that issue and made findings upon it.
Shouldn't that be more an argument to the jury on the credibility of the witness than it should be on the introduction of the right of the defense to confront him with it?
No, I think -- I think not, Your Honor.
My third reason Mr. Justice, (Voice Overlap) --
-- you're thinking that this is a question that must be decided in advance is as I said a moment ago, I think it is a distraction of the jury from the central issue.

On the other hand, does it seem -- does it seem fair for an agent to take a statement which if repeated back to the witness and confirmed by him as being what he had said should be produced at the trial.
-- question was put to it would've answered it in that way?
Your Honor, I had -- have two difficulties with all respect with your statement.
The first is the witness didn't say here, “That's what I said.”
But it happened as he told it.
How did -- how could he be clear as to about something unless he had told it?
He must admit that's the way it happened as I told you it happened.
-- suggest once again and I don't want to forget the second --
No, I didn't say this man was.
I don't think there would be any -- I don't think there'd be any consequences at all.
[Inaudible] -- but Mr. Solicitor General, from the Court's finding [Inaudible]?
Well, I think there's a very -- I think there's a very good illustration of exactly the danger --
[Inaudible] -- you can't deny [Inaudible] defense counsel the Interview Report [Inaudible].
If that was what happened, Your Honor.
But I think it's important to see exactly what happened because this does illustrate curiously the very -- one of the very things that I have been trying to emphasize.
Well, let's look -- because Your Honor, either the first record --
-- or the full text to the Court's opinion in the first Campbell case.
This is on page 213 of the first record.
It's also -- Mr. Justice Brennan gave the page but I didn't get --
May I ask you Mr. General [Inaudible]
[Inaudible] He was looking at the Interview Report and after the judge asked what he had done [Inaudible].
And then he was showing how he paraphrased from his notes.
He's pretending that the Interview Report was the notes.
Well, it would seem to me that if there is this variation between the notes and what the agent said to the witness, certainly he did not read back the notes.
Well, let's assume Mr. Solicitor General.
[Inaudible] precisely what he said -- the witness.
It doesn't -- and the reason for that of course is that if you -- seven hours later dictate precisely what you say, it's the extraordinary chance.
That that is true but there has to be a writing for him to approve.
Now maybe he hypothesized the notes taken and reading back [Inaudible]
I don't think that Your Honors took that last step in the first Campbell.
I really -- if I might just -- I don't think you took the last step.
Well, I think I would be inclined.
But he didn't, we don't know.
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice and members of the Court.
He was the only witness in the entire seven-week trial Mr. Justice Brennan that identified the defendant, Staula.
I'm sorry, I thought the question was of a substantial -- a faithful reproduction of the -- got into -- very closely related.
Yes, but not by the witness necessarily, yes.

Well, Mr. Justice Frankfurter I think covered that both in Palermo and in Campbell when he said, during the proceedings in chambers, and I'm reading from page 107 of 365 U.S., during the proceedings in chambers, the Government repeatedly asserted that the report was not in existence at the time Staula was interviewed.

If I may, Your Honor please, Chief Agent Locklen was asked this question, “What instruction does an agent received Mr. Locklen about approving or checking the accuracy of his notes after an interview with the witness?”
Oh, of course sir, yes sir.
Mr. Chief Justice, just one comment, may it please the Court.
If I may just say in conclusion Mr. Chief Justice, the -- I think the record will bear out the findings of Judge Wyzanski and the petitioners submit that the conviction should be reversed.
